metatags.twitter:title: Does This Video Show Anti-Zelenskyy Billboards in Japan? No!
metatags.author: Abhishek Anand
metatags.og:title: Does This Video Show Anti-Zelenskyy Billboards in Japan? No!
metatags.title: Fact-Check | Does This Video Show Anti-Zelenskyy Billboards Being Put Up in Japan? No!
metatags.og:description: Fact-Check | A digitally altered video is being shared on the internet with a false claim stating that it shows anti-Zelenskyy billboards being put up in Japan.
metatags.twitter:description: We found that the video has been altered to add texts against Zelenskyy on the digital billboard.

ClaimReview.claimReviewed: Video is recent and shows a billboard saying

website_content.content:
A video which shows a digital billboard on a building saying "Stop Zelenskyy, Stop War" is going viral on the internet with users claiming that it was recently put up in 's Shibuya district.
**What have users said?:** Those sharing the video have uploaded it with a caption, "Japan is starting to wake up. An advertising banner appeared on a building in Tokyo, the Shibuya district: 'Stop war. Stop, Zelenskyy'."
!
An archive of the post can be seen .
(Source: X/Screenshot)
A Canadian magazine_, ,_ also shared the video on their official X (formerly known as Twitter) handle. Archives of more similar posts can be viewed , , , and .
**Are these claims true?:** No, the video has been altered to add texts against Ukrainian President . The original video, which dates back to October 2020, featured different people on the billboard.
**How did we find that out?:** Taking Shibuya district as reference, we performed a keyword search on YouTube and came across a video on a verified channel called ''.
*   The video was titled, "4K HDR Night Walk in Tokyo Shibuya (東京散歩)."
*   It was uploaded on 19 October 2020.
*   The longer version also shows people wearing masks, which indicated a possibility of the video being recorded during the pandemic.
...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Quint is a reputable Indian news outlet that provides a range of articles and covers various topics, including international news. While they have a focus on India, they also report on global issues. Their credibility is solid, although they may not always maintain the stringent fact-checking standards that some international publications do. They do provide fact-based reviews, but their editorial slant should be kept in mind when evaluating sources.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence confirms that the video showing the billboard was indeed altered to include the anti-Zelenskyy message. It traces the original video back to October 2020, which supports the assertion that the claim about the billboard is misleading. The specificity about the original content of the video adds significant weight to understanding the authenticity of the viral version.

ClaimReview.claimReviewed: Video shows digital billboard in Japan with

website_content.content:
The claim: Video shows digital billboard in Japan with anti-Zelenskyy message
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
A July 30 post (, ) on X, formerly Twitter, shows video of a crowd crossing a city street at night.
"'Stop Zelensky, Stop War!' In Japan," reads the video's caption, which is describing a message that seems to appear on a digital billboard.
The video was retweeted more than 9,000 times in four days. It was shared on Facebook more than 50 times, according to CrowdTangle, a social media analytics tool.
**Follow us on Facebook!**
Our rating: Altered
-------------------
The video was altered to include the anti-Zelenskyy billboard. The original video shows a different advertisement in its place, and it was posted online more than a year before Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
Video edited to include anti-Zelenskyy display
----------------------------------------------
The clip in the post was taken from a  uploaded to YouTube on Oct. 18, 2020, by a verified account called "Virtual Japan," which posts  in Japan.
It shows the same buildings, vehicles and people as the clip in the post, but the digital billboard in question does not show a message critical of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. Instead, it shows white Japanese writing on a pink background followed by images of people.
An image of the intersection in Shibuya City, Tokyo, taken in October 2022 can be seen on  . The billboard in that image does not show an anti-Zelenskyy billboard either.
**Fact check**: 
The longer video predates Russia's invasion of Ukraine by more than a year.  on Feb. 24, 2022, with Zelenskyy becoming the  of Ukraine's resistance.
Japan has  in response to the invasion, and it has provided  and  to Ukraine. Japan has  that typically prevent it from sending weapons to countries involved in a conflict.
 and  also debunked the claim.
...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: USA Today is a well-established American newspaper known for its broad national coverage and general interest stories. It has decent fact-checking standards and is generally regarded as reliable. However, it can sometimes prioritize accessing a wide audience over in-depth reporting, which might compromise detail in more complex issues.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence explicitly states that the video was altered and clarifies that the original advertisement shown does not feature the anti-Zelenskyy message. It further corroborates the timeline of the original video and connects it to an earlier date than the conflict began, thus rendering the claim suspect.

Was the Banner “Stop Zelenskyy, Stop War” Placed in Japan?
==========================================================
Reading Time: 4 minutes
**Reading Time: 4 minutes**
!
322
VIEWS
! 9
! 9
!
!
!
On July 31 and August 1, 2023, Georgian ()  and Russian-speaking Facebook users (, , ) shared videos and photos of an alleged banner with the following inscription in English: “Stop Zelenskyy, Stop War.” According to the posts, this banner was placed in Japan.
]
**The disseminated video is altered, while the original video was shot in October 2020, and the advertisement on the banner has nothing to do with the Russia-Ukraine war. In addition, the Japanese government issued a pro-Ukraine statement in June 2023, and there is no evidence that an anti-Ukrainian electronic billboard was placed in Japan.**
The video was shot at night and lasts for 12 seconds. Footage shows people crossing the street while the sentence “Stop Zelenskyy, Stop War” is flashing on the electronic billboard. The exact location of the...[Content truncated]

They are recognized for their rigorous adherence to fact-checking principles and have been involved in international collaborations on combating bogus narratives.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source indicates that the video was altered and also provides context about the lack of credible reports regarding the existence of the billboard. While it supports the original claim that the video is manipulated, it could have included more direct comparison to the original video content.

metatags.title: Katy Perry Praises Orlando Bloom's Meeting With Ukraine's President Zelenskyy: 'So Proud'
metatags.body:
Katy Perry took to social media on Monday (March 27) to highlight Orlando Bloom's partnership with UNICEF to help bring humanitarian aid to the children of Ukraine.





"So proud of the work you are doing with @unicef, my love," she wrote alongside her fiancé's video of his in-person meeting with President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. "You are a hero in real life too."



In his own caption, which Perry also reposted, the Carnival Row actor explained the work he's helping with in the embattled country. "Thousands of schools in Ukraine have been damaged or completely destroyed. Thousands of schools in Ukraine have been damaged or completely destroyed. Almost 2.7 million Ukrainian schoolchildren are forced to study online or in a mixed format. About 1.5 million Ukrainian boys and girls are at risk of developing depression, anxiety and other psychological problems.



"During the meeting, we discussed humanitarian aid projects, issues of reconstruction focused specifically on the interests of children," he continued.
metatags.og:description: Katy Perry praised Orlando Bloom's meeting with Ukraine's President Zelenskyy and partnership with UNICEF in helping bring aid to the country.
metatags.twitter:creator: @glennsrowley

metatags.og:title: Tokyo video doctored to add anti-Zelensky billboard
metatags.og:description: A video circulating online appears to show a prominent digital billboard in Japan saying, "Stop war" and "Stop Zelenskyy." But the clip has been doctored; the sign featured people -- not the anti-Ukraine message -- in otherwise matching footage posted to YouTube in 2020, prior to Russia's invasion.

A video circulating online appears to show a prominent digital billboard in Japan saying, "Stop war" and "Stop Zelenskyy." But the clip has been doctored; the sign featured people -- not the anti-Ukraine message -- in otherwise matching footage posted to YouTube in 2020, prior to Russia's invasion.
"Billboard that says 'Stop Zelensky, Stop War' in Japan," says a  from The Post Millennial, a conservative Canadian website that has previously spread .
Screenshot from Twitter, which is being rebranded as "X," taken August 1, 2023
 posts  the  video  across , which is rebranding as "X," and other  such as ,  and .
Screenshot from Twitter, which is being rebranded as "X," taken August 1, 2023
Screenshot from Twitter, which is being rebranded as "X," taken August 1, 2023
The clip also spread in ,  and .
But  (archived ) from nearly three years ago shows the same digital billboard making no mention of the country's war with Russia or its leader, President Volodymyr Zelensky.
AFP found the original video, titled "Night Walk in Tokyo Shibuya," by conducting a  using . It was posted to YouTube on October...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: AFP Fact Check is a renowned fact-checking service provided by Agence France-Presse, one of the oldest news agencies. It has a strong reputation for thorough fact-checking and verifying claims across the globe. Their rigorous standards and detachment from editorial bias make them a top resource for discerning the truth behind claims, especially those circulating on social media.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence explains that the clip featuring the billboard message was doctored, emphasizing that it shows a different advertisement originally. It also includes details about the pre-existing video and its context, which is highly relevant to assessing the authenticity of the claim.

metatags.title: Russia Detains 11 in Attack on Moscow Concert Hall That Killed at Least 133
metatags.body:
Russian authorities arrested four men suspected of carrying out the attack on a suburban Moscow concert hall that killed at least 133 people, President Vladimir Putin said Saturday (March 23) in an address to the nation. He claimed they were captured while fleeing to Ukraine.



Kyiv strongly denied any involvement in Friday’s assault on the Crocus City Hall music venue in Krasnogorsk, and the Islamic State group’s Afghanistan affiliate claimed responsibility.



Putin did not mention IS in his speech, and Kyiv accused him and other Russian politicians of falsely linking Ukraine to the assault to stoke fervor for Russia’s war in Ukraine, which recently entered its third year.



U.S. intelligence officials confirmed the claim by the IS affiliate that it was responsible for the attack, a U.S. official told The Associated Press. U.S. intelligence agencies gathered information in recent weeks that the IS branch was planning an attack in Moscow, and U.S. officials privately shared the intelligence with R
metatags.og:description: Vladimir Putin said Russian authorities detained a total of 11 people, including four suspected gunmen who attacked concertgoers in Moscow.

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... 2023
!
!
!
The Japanese anti-Zelenskyy sign was manipulated (Twitter)
Emerging story
--------------
Social media users, mainly pro-Russia, circulated a video purporting to feature a banner on a building in Japan with the message: "Stop Zelenskyy! Stop the war!"
!
Misleading
The Claim
---------
A video shows a banner displayed on a building in Japan that reads: "Stop Zelenskyy! Stop the war!"
News posted on
--------------
Spriter]Towhee]Luis]Leandro]Keithb]
Misbar’s Analysis
-----------------
 investigated the widely circulated video and found the claim to be fake.
The video is digitally altered to show the anti-Zelensky billboard.
The Video Showing a Japanese Anti-Zelenskyy Sign Was Manipulated
----------------------------------------------------------------
The original video does not feature the  billboard. The original video dates back to October 19, 2020. The footage shows a person walking around the bustling Shibuya neighborhood in Tokyo, , and videotaping the scene.
!
_**Photo Description:** A screenshot of the original video from YouTube._
's team compared the viral video with the longer original version and discovered that the viral video appears approximately 21:25 into the original video.
!
_**Photo Description:** A screenshot of the original video and the circulating video._
According to the 2022 guidelines set by the Japanese Consumer Affairs Agency, it is not clear whether such a billboard, if real, would be considered prohibited since it does not promote any product or have any affiliation with a Japanese political party or organization.
Furthermore, no reliable media outlets reported the video showing the anti-Zelenskyy message.
Shibuya AI Vision
-----------------
The advertisement banner seen in the video is known as Shibuya Ai Vision. Reports indicate that it is a large vertical screen used to convey messages related to love, birthdays, and special occasions to people globally.
The screen is located near other commercial centers, such as Shibuya Modi and Shibuya 109, with their main entrance at Shibuya crossing, a famous and bustling scramble crossing in Tokyo. Moreover, Shibuya boasts two of the busiest railway stations in the world, namely Shibuya and Shinjuku stations.
!
_**Photo Description:** A screenshot of Shibuya Ai Vision from the Webcam taxi website._
Russia-Ukraine Disinformation War
---------------------------------
As the  invasion of  unfolds, both the Russian state and state-controlled media have engaged in an information war by disseminating disinformation. In response, Ukrainian media and politicians...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Misbar is dedicated to fact-checking and combating misinformation. They provide analyses of false claims as well as underlying evidence to refute them. Their commitment to transparency and clarity on the sources they employ contributes positively to their credibility.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence confirms that the circulating video was manipulated and ties the original video back to 2020. Additionally, it provides useful context about the video’s manipulation and the nature of the Billboard, which is relevant to evaluating the claim.

metatags.title: Brad Paisley on Recording New Song ‘Same Here’ With Ukrainian President Zelenskyy: 'I Feel Like I’m In The Bourne Identity'
metatags.body:
When Brad Paisley started playing potential songs from  his forthcoming album Son of the Mountains for Universal Music Group Nashville president Cindy Mabe, she told him, “Make music that matters, that’s not disposable.” 







Gentle ballad “Same Here” was in the first batch that he played her, and Paisley certainly took that message to heart. The song, which came out Friday (Feb. 24), celebrates our similarities no matter where we’re from or the language we speak and ends with the audio of a conversation between the country superstar and Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy. The release date is not coincidental: Today marks a year since Russia invaded its neighbor. 





UMGN sent the track to radio, but even Paisley, whose 12th No. 1 on Billboard’s Country Airplay chart was last February’s “Freedom Was a Highway” with Jimmie Allen, doesn’t expect it to garner much play and he’s fine with that — even though, as he points out, “It’s a very country record,” with Jerry

metatags.article:author: Reuters Fact Check
metatags.twitter:description: Video of a digital billboard on a busy street in Japan has been edited to replace the advertisements on the screen with a message against Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy reading: “stop Zelenskyy, stop war.”

website_content.content: Error fetching https://www.reuters.com/article/factcheck-japan-zelenskiy/fact-check-billboard-in-japan-displaying-anti-zelenskiy-message-is-altered-idUSL1N39J0XW: 451 Client Error: Unavailable For Legal Reasons for url: https://r.jina.ai/https://www.reuters.com/article/factcheck-japan-zelenskiy/fact-check-billboard-in-japan-displaying-anti-zelenskiy-message-is-altered-idUSL1N39J0XW

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Reuters is a reputable international news organization known for its strict adherence to journalistic integrity and factual reporting. Their emphasis on accuracy and commitment to uncovering the truth make them a reliable source for checking information. They are widely used as a reference for news verification.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence effectively confirms that the video has been manipulated and discusses the anti-Zelenskyy message. It provides insight into the circumstances surrounding the video's spread, and helps establish that the claim of the billboard's existence is unfounded.

metatags.og:description: Following Zelenskyy’s address to world leaders this week, many on social media shared a video and images of the fabricated ad, claiming that the message was live as the Ukrainian president arrived in the Big Apple.
metatags.twitter:creator: @melissa_goldin
metatags.twitter:image:alt:
**HOLD FOR STORY**
Tourists are seen in New York’s Times Square, Thursday, Sept. 30, 2021. After New York City's deadliest summer in a decade last year, this one started off looking just as bad, with two killings before dawn on the season's first day. But then the slayings slowed and fears of another abnormally bloody summer in the Big Apple didn't pan out. Homicide totals for the three-month period from June 21 to Sept. 22 ended closer to pre-pandemic levels, welcome relief for a city that has prided itself on being one of the safest in America. (AP Photo/Mary Altaffer)

metatags.twitter:description: Following Zelenskyy’s address to world leaders this week, many on social media shared a video and images of the fabricated ad, claiming that the message was live as the Ukrainian president arrived in the Big Apple.
